timeline.message: making key fetch logic thread safe

timeline.bodyText: Shouldn't you be asserting the UNWRAP_KEY permission?
timeline.author: heaths

replies.bodyText:
yup, thanks for the catch.
Updated.
replies.author: g2vinay

timeline.bodyText: Nit: here and the line below spends time negating, which slows things down a little but also makes readability more difficult. Could maybe be simplified.
timeline.author: heaths

timeline.bodyText: Should this maybe be setKey? Not sure if that's idiomatic, but I thought normally setting objects uses the "set" prefix.
timeline.author: heaths
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -299,4 +300,18 @@ public CryptographyClientBuilder serviceVersion(CryptographyServiceVersion versi this.version = version; return this; } + + /** + * Sets the jsonWebKey to be used for cryptography operations. + * + *

If {@code key} is provided then it takes precedence over key identifier and gets used for cryptography + * operations.

+ * + * @param key The key to be used for cryptography operations. + * @return the updated builder object. + */ + CryptographyClientBuilder key(KeyVaultKey key) {

replies.bodyText: It should just be 'key' - we leave the 'set' prefix off in builders. However, this method is package-private, so it is either Javadoc'd unnecessarily, or it should have been made public and been API reviewed, or it is only used internally and this is intentional - and should be commented as such to make that decision clear. From what I can see it is the last point - it is intended for internal use only.
replies.author: JonathanGiles

replies.bodyText:
Yeah, it is meant to be internal.
The javadoc is as good as a comment currently.
Will possibly exposed in future, when we decide to make this public across all languages.
replies.author: g2vinay

timeline.bodyText: Seems this should either be name or ID. Since the name derives from the ID, both shouldn't be necessary.
timeline.author: heaths

replies.bodyText:
Okay, that's true too.
Refactored this.
replies.author: g2vinay

timeline.bodyText: What motivated your introduction of the AtomicReference type?
timeline.author: JonathanGiles

replies.bodyText: On second thought, redesigned to keep it non atomic.
replies.author: g2vinay

timeline.bodyText: This would be more readable with a switch statement
timeline.author: JonathanGiles

replies.bodyText: Expandable String enum, cannot do that, as discussed.
replies.author: g2vinay

timeline.bodyText: These exceptions do not clearly state what the user should do to resolve the issue. More specificity means less confusion for end users.
timeline.author: JonathanGiles

timeline.bodyText: Should this method be named buildAsyncKeyEncryptionKeyClient?
timeline.author: srnagar

replies.bodyText:
This is used by other SDKs which utilize AsyncKEK and KEK.
So, from user perspective, they will use KV to build what other SDKs consume,
this will be straight to the point and less confusing.
replies.author: g2vinay

timeline.bodyText: Good to have null checks on these helper methods.
timeline.author: srnagar

timeline.bodyText: You probably want to store the entire KeyVaultKey so that you can validate the current time is in between notBefore expiresOn when performing encrypt, sign, and wapKey. But you could file an issue on this now and do a separate PR for it.
timeline.author: schaabs
